items.title: Cloud Endpoints, support Google App Engine Standard for Python 3.x
items.body:
I have 2 questions.

1. When will Cloud Endpoints support Google App Engine (GAE) standard environment for python 3.x? 
As you know, in https://cloud.google.com/endpoints/docs/frameworks/python/get-started-frameworks-python, "Note: Make sure you have Python 2.7.x installed. python 3.x isn't supported by Endpoints Frameworks." Even though python 2.7.x is end of support this year, I can not upgrade to python 3 using Endpoints Frameworks in GAE standard environment. 
Unfortunately, I could not find out features in this repository.

2. If the Endpoints Frameworks is not supported for GAE standard for python 3, what library should I use?

Kind Regards,

items.title: cachetools conflict with firebase-admin
items.body:
You require:
google-endpoints-api-management
which is also requiring:
google-auth

but firebase-admin depends upon:
google-api-core which requires :
google-auth<2.0dev,>=0.4.0

so I'm getting this error:
google-auth 1.6.3 has requirement cachetools>=2.0.0, but you'll have cachetools 1.1.6 which is incompatible.

Also can you please make a note on the README.MD that using endpoints FORCES you to ignore advice elsewhere on the net to use virtualenv (instead of vendoring) with GAE-standard

items.title: get_swagger_spec causes AttributeError: 'Namespace' object has no attribute 'x_google_api_name'
items.body:
# Repro
1. clone https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/python-docs-samples
1. cd ~/python-docs-samples/appengine/standard/endpoints-frameworks-v2/echo
1. pip install --system -t lib google-endpoints>=4.8.0
1. python ./lib/endpoints/endpointscfg.py  get_swagger_spec main.api

# Error
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./lib/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 31, in <module>
    main(sys.argv)
  File "/home/ksbae/python-docs-samples/appengine/standard/endpoints/backend/lib/endpoints/_endpointscfg_impl.py", line 617, in main
    args.callback(args)
  File "/home/ksbae/python-docs-samples/appengine/standard/endpoints/backend/lib/endpoints/_endpointscfg_impl.py", line 465, in _GenOpenApiSpecCallback
    x_google_api_name=args.x_google_api_name)
```

Please tell me if I'm missing something.

items.title: api_key shouldn't count as an issuer for audience purposes
items.body: In 4.7.0, OpenAPI generation raises a 'audiences must be a dict when third-party issuers are in use' exception if non-Google Auth issuers are in use. However, api_key is technically treated as an issuer, even though it's a different kind of security control. Ignore api_key for these purposes.

items.title: During generation of client API (Java / Android): Wrong "True" value
items.body:
```java /** * Convenience method that returns only {@link Boolean#TRUE} or {@link Boolean#FALSE}. * *

* Boolean properties can have four possible values: * {@code null}, {@link com.google.api.client.util.Data#NULL_BOOLEAN}, {@link Boolean#TRUE} * or {@link Boolean#FALSE}. *

* *

* This method returns {@link Boolean#TRUE} if the default of the property is {@link Boolean#TRUE} * and it is {@code null} or {@link com.google.api.client.util.Data#NULL_BOOLEAN}. * {@link Boolean#FALSE} is returned if the default of the property is {@link Boolean#FALSE} and * it is {@code null} or {@link com.google.api.client.util.Data#NULL_BOOLEAN}. *

* *

* *

*/ public boolean isSomething() { if (isSomething == null || isSomething == com.google.api.client.util.Data.NULL_BOOLEAN) { return True; } return isSomething; } ``` In above-generated code, in Java / Android, the function return "`True`" instead of java's "`true`" (small "`t`"). it generate only when I set "`default=True`" or "`default=False`". ```python class X(messages.Message): is_something = messages.BooleanField(19) ```

items.title: Add 'required' for body parameters
items.body:
https://github.com/cloudendpoints/endpoints-python/blob/2bd41f4c40f6ba2844ac88c9f2f4f82f06bac23c/endpoints/openapi_generator.py#L372-L380

The body message effectively is required, so we should put that in the generated spec.

items.title: Handle audiences dict properly for service account auth
items.body:
https://github.com/cloudendpoints/endpoints-python/blob/21d7e9753a9ba0b26c2380171d33cd338e2fcb08/endpoints/users_id_token.py#L222-L223

Sometimes, audiences is a dict with issuers as keys and audiences as values. When this happens, we need to determine the active issuer and select the appropriate value. We can't do this if we don't pass the real issuers in.

items.title: `request_message_descriptor` should not allow request bodies on `NO_BODY` request types
items.body:
https://github.com/cloudendpoints/endpoints-python/blob/3ccb44c8a0a6835d961e4850e5c51eb92eb92ce5/endpoints/openapi_generator.py#L597-L600

Failure to throw an exception here leads to a confusing exception within `body_parameter_descriptor` later on, as seen [here](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/google-cloud-endpoints/phd8kQGCaps/W4Cgm_OBAAAJ).

items.title: endpointscfg get_discovery_doc uses external service; shouldn't.

somehow this didn't get converted to use discovery_generator.py.

items.title: token_info 'verified_email'
items.body:
Hi,
Hopefully i am posting this in the correct place.  We have noticed that in the file 'users_id_token.py' that when the email address is being verified it is using.
`  if token_info.get('verified_email'):
    _logger.warning('Oauth token email isn\'t verified.')
    return
`
However, upon checking the responses from 'https://www.googleapis.com/oauth2/v1/tokeninfo?access_token=xxx' that sometimes 'verified_email' is returned and other times 'email_verified' is returned.  When 'email_verified' is returned the error is triggers.  

Presently we have monkey patched the code to check for both, but thought I would alert you nonetheless.

Many thanks

items.title: messages.IntegerField converted into string
items.body:
messages.IntegerField isn't handled properly in JSON responses.
If you try to define and use a message with an integer field (for example `amount`), the JSON response will be an object that contains a property with a string value instead of an integer value (in the example `{ "amount": "12345"}`), the integer value assigned is always converted into a string.

items.title: 3rd Party Auth - Auth0
items.body:
Hello,

I'm trying to use Auth0 for authentication and following the [documentation](https://cloud.google.com/endpoints/docs/frameworks/java/authenticating-users#authenticating_with_auth0), this simply doesn't work. 

I'm getting this error: `id_token verification failed: Invalid token signature`

Debugging this thing, seems like the code are checking the url `https://www.googleapis.com/service_accounts/v1/metadata/raw/federated-signon@system.gserviceaccount.com` and not the Auth0 jkws url.

For reference, I'm **not** using local dev environment.

Thanks in advance

items.title: 3rd-Party Auth Client Credentials Grant
items.body:
Hey, 

I'm trying to request my api with a [Client Credentials Grant](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.4) access token, but it seems to fail when tries to get `user_info.email` (I guess) which is None, because Client Credentials Grant doesn't have user info.

https://github.com/cloudendpoints/endpoints-python/blob/4766d87b4d66379d350848754a1d1670aae12aba/endpoints/users_id_token.py#L119

Api definition:

`@endpoints.api(name='todo',version='v1', audiences={'auth0': ["http://api.todo.com"]},
        issuers={'auth0': endpoints.Issuer("https://todo.eu.auth0.com/","https://todo.eu.auth0.com/.well-known/jwks.json")})`

Any idea how to do this?

In other words, are endpoints standard framework v2 prepared to deal with access tokens?

items.title: Newly deployed apps cannot run
items.body:
https://github.com/python-attrs/attrs/issues/284

Because attrs 17.3.0 uses the `ctypes` library, any apps deployed using this version cannot properly initialize.

The current fix is to peg the version at 17.2.0.

please add support for both prefixes:
`/_ah/spi/...` and `/_ah/api/...`

For spi, I am having issue with `/_ah/spi/BackendService.getApiConfigs` with v2 version.

items.title: 2.4.1 breaks unpredictably
items.body:
Because 2.4.1 introduces a file named `types.py` and the framework generally relies on relative imports, depending on how `api_config.py` is imported, `import types as endpoints_types` may import `endpoints.types` or it may import `types`, the Python standard library.

We should switch to absolute imports as soon as is feasible and use the `from __future__ import absolute_import` directive.

In the meantime, we can issue a quick fix by renaming `types.py` to `endpoints_types.py`

items.title: Specifying multiple issuers should generate OR'ed security requirements
Tests do not run in App Engine environment
items.body:
`endpointscfg.py` uses `google.appengine.ext.testbed` to set up an appengine environment. Tox doesn't do anything of the sort.

This has caused subtle environmental differences that lead to bugs.

There are several unofficial pip-installable SDKs, but nothing up to date.

items.title: six v1.11.0 breaks endpoints
items.body:
Six version 1.11 has changed the way with_metaclass works, this cause ALL users of endpoints to fail upon running in dev_server or production with the following call stack (prod): 

Error when calling the metaclass bases metaclass conflict: the metaclass of a derived class must be a (non-strict) subclass of the metaclasses of all its bases

/lib/apitools/base/protorpclite/messages.py:1165 at <module> /lib/endpoints_management/gen/servicecontrol_v1_messages.py:24 at <module> /lib/endpoints_management/control/__init__.py:19 at <module> /lib/endpoints_management/__init__.py:17 at <module> lib/endpoints/apiserving.py:74 at <module> /lib/endpoints/__init__.py:29 at <module> 
main.py:2

I don't know if this issue should be attributed to the six package or to endpoints but for now  you need to freeze six at 1.10.0 in order to make it work.

items.title: Multiple service classes in one server should generate one openapi file
items.body: Currently it generates a file for each service, which is incorrect. There are probably several bugs that are caused by this.

items.title: schemes always set to http when generating openapi spec
items.body:
```protocol = 'http' if ((hostname and hostname.startswith('localhost')) or util.is_running_on_devserver()) else 'https'```

`is_running_on_devserver()` is always true when running locally to generate the spec. This is not desired behavior.

I think this is an error in #14.

items.title: Spec generation basePath bug
items.body:
In v2, if the base path is set to root like so
```python
# resolves to /api/
api_collection = endpoints.api(name='api', version='v1', base_path='/')
```
then this incorrectly produces a spec with the basePath to nothing `""`
```json
{
  "basePath": "/",
  "consumes": [
    "application/json"
  ],
```
when it should leave it as root `"/"`

items.title: Error while deploying openApi files (Migration v1 to v2.)
items.body:
Following is the structure of my project
![screen shot 2017-08-07 at 8 02 46 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17262180/29031327-7b872c0c-7bab-11e7-9951-18926ff6f8e0.png)

I have written two APIs (`OrdersApi` and `UsersApi`) in two separate files (`orders.py` and `users.py`). For both `version='v1'`

I generated the Open API configuration files for both APIs by running the following commands

`python lib/endpoints/endpointscfg.py get_openapi_spec apis.OrdersApi apis.UsersApi --hostname office-needs.appspot.com`

This gave me two files `ordersv1openapi.json`  and `usersv1openapi.json`.

But when I run 
`gcloud service-management deploy ordersv1openapi.json usersv1openapi.json `
I get the following error

```
ERROR: (gcloud.service-management.deploy) INVALID_ARGUMENT: kind: ERROR
message: "Multiple OpenAPI files cannot have the same \'info.version\' value. Files and Versions found: {ordersv1openapi.json:v1, usersv1openapi.json:v1}"
```

items.title: 'Path used multiple times' when migrating to v2
items.body:
(Also on [Stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45480401/path-used-multiple-times-when-migrating-to-google-cloud-enpoints-v2))

Hello

I tried to follow [the steps to migrate to v2](https://cloud.google.com/endpoints/docs/frameworks/legacy/v1/python/migrating) (appengine app) and faced what seems to be a bug.

I have multiple APIs under the same AppEngine service (pretty much like [here](https://github.com/cloudendpoints/endpoints-python/issues/47)), and changed my `app.yaml`, downloaded the `cloud-endpoints` library, put it in the `/lib` folder...

Then I pushed the code to AppEngine, using ` gcloud app deploy` only (at this time I did not know about `gcloud service-management`, we were not using this before).

When trying to call one of my endpoints then, I got this error 'ApiConfigurationError: POST path "synchro" used multiple times, in classes SQL and Synchro'

That's true, but those two methods are under differents APIs so it should work (it does, in v1).

My code

```
@endpoints.api(name="sql", version='v1.0')
class SQL(remote.Service):
   @endpoints.method(
        CREATE_SYNCHRO,
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        path='synchro',
        http_method='POST',
        name='synchros.start'
    )

@endpoints.api(name='synchro', version='v1.0')
class Synchro(remote.Service):
    @endpoints.method(
        DayUserList,
        UserList,
        path='synchro',
        http_method='POST',
        name='synchronisation'
    )
```
(So migrating from v1 to v2 does not seem to be as simple as Google says... :) )

items.title: Versioning class Endpoints
items.body: Hi, I migrated from v1 to v2 and I am having this issue: I cannot perform versioning for two different services ``` test_collection_v1 = endpoints.api(name='test', version='v1') test_collection_v2 = endpoints.api(name='test', version='v2') ``` ``` @test_collection_v1.api_class() class TestApi(remote.Service): @endpoints.method( message_types.VoidMessage, message_types.VoidMessage, name='alive', path='alive', http_method='GET') def alive(self, request): # behavior 1 return message_types.VoidMessage() ``` ``` @test_collection_v2.api_class() class TestApiV2(remote.Service): @endpoints.method( message_types.VoidMessage, message_types.VoidMessage, name='alive', path='alive', http_method='GET') def alive(self, request): # behavior 2 (different from 1) return message_types.VoidMessage() ``` `application = endpoints.api_server([TestApi, TestApiV2], restricted=False)` Error:

items.title: Deploy endpoints 2.0 in an app engine old version isn't updating api explorer
items.body:
I'm trying to update an app version appengine called "development" and was **created with endpoints 1.0** with endpoints version **2.0**. 

When I update the "development" version with endpoints 2.0 and I go to Api Explorer, the Api Explorer still with the old version of the API (created with endpoints 1.0).
When I do the deploy in a new version called "development-endpoints2o" and I go to Api Explorer, it works correctly.

Has anyone ever had this problem?
I think it's kind of  cache problem or something. Is there any way to solve this?

I'm using python with endpoints 2.0.6.
Thanks.

items.title: get_openapi_spec will only generate schemes with "http"
items.body:
I can't figure out how to generate a open api spec json file with the correct schemes that would include "https", when I generate my file locally with a command like this:

`$python lib/endpoints/endpointscfg.py get_openapi_spec main.CoreApi --hostname core-api-dot-dev-sada-gcs.appspot.com`

util.is_running_on_devserver() will always return this as being a "Development" server because locally I'm using google cloud SDK to generate the spec file.

Am I doing this wrong? Is there a better way to do this that will generate the spec file with an "https" in schemes?

https://github.com/cloudendpoints/endpoints-python/blob/e27f8b057c6e30148a87aec6d66f6f174a7c80a8/endpoints/util.py#L190-L191

items.title: Latest gcloud version breaks endpointscfg gen_client_lib
items.body:
The latest version of `gcloud` has deprecated the `application` key in `app.yaml` which is required for `gen_client_lib` to create a working library (for Java at least in my limited testing).

`gcloud version` output:

```Google Cloud SDK 148.0.0
app-engine-python 1.9.50
bq 2.0.24
bq-nix 2.0.24
core 2017.03.17
core-nix 2017.03.13
gcloud 
gcloud-deps 2017.03.17
gcloud-deps-linux-x86_64 2017.03.13
gsutil 4.23
gsutil-nix 4.22
```

items.title: Problems with endpointscfg.py script (ImportError: No module named _endpointscfg_setup)
items.body:
Hi there,

I've discovered a number of problems with the current implementation of `endpointscfg.py`, could you please comment on them and maybe suggest a workaround or a fix.

1. I use buildout to setup my development environment, that means all packages are installed as eggs and scripts with appropriate `sys.path` patching are placed under bin/ directory. Here is what I get when try to run `bin/endpointscfg.py` script:
    ```
    ./bin/endpointscfg.py get_openapi_spec main.EchoApi --hostname echo-api.endpoints.my-test-project.appspot.com
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "./bin/endpointscfg.py", line 89, in <module>
        import _endpointscfg_setup  # pylint: disable=unused-import
    ImportError: No module named _endpointscfg_setup
    ```
    Seems that the script has to be ran from it's source directory, which is very inconvenient.
2. OpenAPI configuration generation apparently involves application loading (`main.py`) but `appengine_config.py` file is not executed before that in contrast to when application is ran with `dev_appserver.py` for example. So, all the code to setup paths properly I have in the `appengine_config.py` needs to be duplicated somewhere...
3. The last it would be very nice to be able to run the script and not necessarily be in the application root directory, just point it to the app root directory instead.

items.title: endpoints 2.0.2 - How to generate (and successfully upload) a swagger specification for multiple APIs?
items.body:
While trying to migrate an existing Endpoints 1.0 GAE Standard project to endpoints framework 2.0, I also ran into trouble trying to figure out how to deploy the multiple Swagger/OpenAPI configuration files for all of the APIs hosted in my application.

Given:

```python
import endpoints
from protorpc import message_types, remote


@endpoints.api(
    name='someapi',
    version='v1',
    allowed_client_ids=[endpoints.API_EXPLORER_CLIENT_ID],
    scopes=[endpoints.EMAIL_SCOPE]
)
class SomeApiService(remote.Service):

    @endpoints.method(
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        path='someaction',
        http_method='GET',
        name='someaction',
    )
    def someaction(self, request):
        return message_types.VoidMessage()


@endpoints.api(
    name='anotherapi',
    version='v1',
    allowed_client_ids=[endpoints.API_EXPLORER_CLIENT_ID],
    scopes=[endpoints.EMAIL_SCOPE]
)
class AnotherApiV1Service(remote.Service):

    @endpoints.method(
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        path='anotheraction',
        http_method='GET',
        name='anotheraction',
    )
    def anotheraction(self, request):
        return message_types.VoidMessage()

@endpoints.api(
    name='anotherapi',
    version='v2',
    allowed_client_ids=[endpoints.API_EXPLORER_CLIENT_ID],
    scopes=[endpoints.EMAIL_SCOPE]
)
class AnotherApiV2Service(remote.Service):

    @endpoints.method(
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        path='anotheraction',
        http_method='GET',
        name='anotheraction',
    )
    def anotheraction(self, request):
        return message_types.VoidMessage()


APPLICATION = endpoints.api_server([SomeApiService, AnotherApiV1Service, AnotherApiV2Service])
```

And then running the following commands:
```
$ python2.7 lib/endpoints/endpointscfg.py get_openapi_spec main.SomeApiService --hostname peerless-rite-129222.appspot.com
No handlers could be found for logger "endpoints.apiserving"
OpenAPI spec written to ./someapiv1openapi.json
$ python2.7 lib/endpoints/endpointscfg.py get_openapi_spec main.AnotherApiV1Service --hostname peerless-rite-129222.appspot.com
No handlers could be found for logger "endpoints.apiserving"
OpenAPI spec written to ./anotherapiv1openapi.json
$ python2.7 lib/endpoints/endpointscfg.py get_openapi_spec main.AnotherApiV2Service --hostname peerless-rite-129222.appspot.com
No handlers could be found for logger "endpoints.apiserving"
OpenAPI spec written to ./anotherapiv2openapi.json
$ CLOUDSDK_CORE_PROJECT=peerless-rite-129222 gcloud service-management deploy *.json
Enabling service endpoints.googleapis.com on project peerless-rite-129222...
Waiting for async operation operations/projectSettings.1712a953-72b6-4b5c-8557-486eda5c9ce7 to complete...
Operation finished successfully. The following command can describe the Operation details:
$ gcloud service-management operations describe operations/projectSettings.1712a953-72b6-4b5c-8557-486eda5c9ce7
ERROR: (gcloud.service-management.deploy) INVALID_ARGUMENT: kind: ERROR
message: "Multiple OpenAPI files cannot have the same \'info.version\' value. Files and Versions found: {anotherapiv1openapi.json:v1, anotherapiv2openapi.json:v2, someapiv1openapi.json:v1}"
```

So it seems like I am not able to deploy Swagger configurations for multiple endpoints framework APIs on the same domain/project/module/service, that have the same version string?

items.title: endpoints 2.0.2 - Hosting multiple APIs causes a 500 when client discovery APIs are called
items.body:
In endpoints python 1.0, it was possible to host multiple APIs on a single Google Appengine Standard service/module. However, my attempts to port a endpoints application with multiple APIs has been problematic. After upgrading to endpoints 2.0, when I try to point APIs Explorer at my instance, the discovery API calls trigger 500 errors:

```
ApiConfigurationError: Attempting to implement service resultsapi, version v1, with multiple classes that are not compatible. See docstring for api() for examples how to implement a multi-class API.

        at __get_merged_api_info (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name/20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/discovery_generator.py:833)
        at __discovery_doc_descriptor (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name/20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/discovery_generator.py:855)
        at get_discovery_doc (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name/20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/discovery_generator.py:1007)
        at pretty_print_config_to_json (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/discovery_generator.py:1021)
        at _get_rest_doc (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name/20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/discovery_service.py:108)
        at handle_discovery_request (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name/20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/discovery_service.py:203)
        at call_backend (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name/20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/endpoints_dispatcher.py:337)
        at dispatch (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name/20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/endpoints_dispatcher.py:149)
        at __call__ (/base/data/home/apps/some-gae-project-name/20170222t161647.399372013217524367/lib/endpoints/endpoints_dispatcher.py:117)
        at Handle (/base/data/home/runtimes/python27/python27_lib/versions/1/google/appengine/runtime/wsgi.py:268)
```

I have several services that each implement a single API via an API decorator, as well as an API that is implemented by multiple services. This works fine in endpoints 1.0.

If I run it locally via dev appserver and inject pdb into `lib/endpoints/discovery_generatory.py` inside of `DiscoveryGenerator.__get_merged_api_info()` to inspect the services it receives, it is getting all of my services for all of my APIs, which raises the above exception because when it sees services for different APIs.

items.title: x-issuer and x-jwks_uri Extensions Are Deprecated
items.body:
The Google Cloud SDK is giving the following warning to openapi specifications generated by endpoints:

> WARNING: mysystemv1.0openapi.json: x-issuer: Extension name x-issuer has been deprecated, please rename it to x-google-issuer.
WARNING: mysystemv1.0openapi.json: x-jwks_uri: Extension name x-jwks_uri has been deprecated, please rename it to x-google-jwks_uri.

openapi_generator.py probably just needs a small edit to rename them.

items.title: Discovery doc not generating on GAE
items.body:
I'm having an issue with my application that I've not been able to solve. Everything had been working fine, and as I have made very minimal changes since version 2.0.0b7 of endpoints-python was released, I'm posting this issue as I believe the source of the error may be originating inside endpoints-python.

For testing purposes, I make use of Google's API explorer tool to easily make calls against my api. This has been working fine. Now though, I'm getting an error in my logs that reads as follows:

> No discovery doc for version 1.0 of api...

This originates at discovery_service.py:115.

I get this error every time I try to use the API Explorer, which I assume queries the discovery service. However, upon further digging, I noticed that I don't get the same error when I'm on the [default] service; it only happens when I'm within a named service, as defined (or not) in my app.yaml files.

For example, if my app.yaml is as follows:

```
runtime: python27
threadsafe: true
api_version: 1

...skip files stuff....

handlers:
- url: /_ah/api/.*
  script: core.api
```

All is well. But if I include:

`service: telephony`

Then discovery generation fails.

Digging a little deeper I noticed that when I visit:

`https://telephony-dot-REDACTED.appspot.com/_ah/api/discovery/v1/apis`

The discovery JSON that I get is as follows:

```
{
 "kind": "discovery#directoryList",
 "discoveryVersion": "v1",
 "items": [
  {
   "kind": "discovery#directoryItem",
   "id": "telephony:v1.0",
   "name": "telephony",
   "version": "v1.0",
   "title": "Wrapped Telephony services",
   "description": "This is an API",
   "discoveryRestUrl": "https://REDACTED.appspot.com/_ah/api/discovery/v1/apis/telephony/v1.0/rest",
   "discoveryLink": "./apis/telephony/v1.0/rest",
   "icons": {
    "x16": "https://www.gstatic.com/images/branding/product/1x/googleg_16dp.png",
    "x32": "https://www.gstatic.com/images/branding/product/1x/googleg_32dp.png"
   },
   "preferred": true
  }
 ]
}
```

Note that the `discoveryRestUrl` above is incorrect. It should be:

`https://telephony.REDACTED.appspot.com/_ah/api/discovery/v1/apis/telephony/v1.0/rest`

-or-

`https://telephony-dot-REDACTED.appspot.com/_ah/api/discovery/v1/apis/telephony/v1.0/rest`

If I then browse to the correct URL, I get a valid REST discovery JSON file, which in my case, begins as follows:

```
{
  "auth": {
    "oauth2": {
      "scopes": {
        "https://www.googleapis.com/auth/userinfo.email": {
          "description": "View your email address"
        }
      }
    }
  },
  "basePath": "/_ah/api/telephony/v1.0/",
  "baseUrl": "https://REDACTED.appspot.com/_ah/api/telephony/v1.0/",
  "batchPath": "batch",
  "discoveryVersion": "v1",
  "icons": {
    "x16": "http://www.google.com/images/icons/product/search-16.gif",
    "x32": "http://www.google.com/images/icons/product/search-32.gif"
  },
  "id": "telephony:v1.0",
  "kind": "discovery#restDescription",
  "name": "telephony",
  "parameters": {

...
```

Here I'm less sure, but I believe the `baseUrl` should also contain the service name, no?

I've reviewed the recent changes to discovery_service.py, but the recent introduction of discovery_generator.py (and therefore lack of change history to review) all but collapsed my desire to dig much further for an easy fix.

For completeness sake, I did test using the local development server, but didn't get the same behaviour because the development tool doesn't seem to serve differently if a service name is provided. So, the discovery docs seem to be right as they should be. Oddly though, locally, I can't get the API Explorer to actually load the api. Yes, I'm configuring Chrome correctly, per the documentation. The API Explorer loads up, but it won't show my api, even for the one that works fine on App Engine. Perhaps running endpoints locally still doesn't work?

I'm sorry if this is unclear. I'm happy to provide further details. My implementation is very basic, so my feeling is that this should work, as it had been. I've not made any changes to my app.yaml file recently (except updating the `ENDPOINTS_SERVICE_VERSION` as required). My api classes have also not changed since it was last working.

I'm on:

endpoints v2.0.0b7
endpoints_api_management v1.0.0b9
gcloud sdk v138.0.0 with updated components.

I'm using the App Engine SDK packaged within the Cloud SDK.

My endpoints classes use the api_collection decorator so I can have multiple classes.

Interested in whatever thoughts you may have. I'd really like this to be working again so I can continue testing.

items.title: Endpoints 2.0.0b7 '_ApiDecorator' object has no attribute 'base_path'
items.body:
Discovered while attempting to modify the EchoApi example code from https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/python-docs-samples/tree/master/appengine/standard/endpoints-frameworks-v2/echo to support multiple api classes.

I don't know if this is officially supported yet or not, but #27 seems to imply that it should work. 

```python
# [START imports]
import endpoints
from protorpc import message_types
from protorpc import messages
from protorpc import remote
# [END imports]


# [START messages]
class EchoRequest(messages.Message):
    content = messages.StringField(1)


class EchoResponse(messages.Message):
    """A proto Message that contains a simple string field."""
    content = messages.StringField(1)


ECHO_RESOURCE = endpoints.ResourceContainer(
    EchoRequest,
    n=messages.IntegerField(2, default=1))
# [END messages]


# [START echo_api]
api_collection = endpoints.api(
    name='library',
    version='v1')


@api_collection.api_class(resource_name='echo')
class Echo(remote.Service):

    @endpoints.method(
        # This method takes a ResourceContainer defined above.
        ECHO_RESOURCE,
        # This method returns an Echo message.
        EchoResponse,
        path='echo',
        http_method='POST',
        name='echo')
    def echo(self, request):
        output_content = ' '.join([request.content] * request.n)
        return EchoResponse(content=output_content)

    @endpoints.method(
        # This method takes a ResourceContainer defined above.
        ECHO_RESOURCE,
        # This method returns an Echo message.
        EchoResponse,
        path='echo/{n}',
        http_method='POST',
        name='echo_path_parameter')
    def echo_path_parameter(self, request):
        output_content = ' '.join([request.content] * request.n)
        return EchoResponse(content=output_content)

    @endpoints.method(
        # This method takes a ResourceContainer defined above.
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        # This method returns an Echo message.
        EchoResponse,
        path='echo/getApiKey',
        http_method='GET',
        name='echo_api_key')
    def echo_api_key(self, request):
        return EchoResponse(content=request.get_unrecognized_field_info('key'))

    @endpoints.method(
        # This method takes an empty request body.
        message_types.VoidMessage,
        # This method returns an Echo message.
        EchoResponse,
        path='echo/getUserEmail',
        http_method='GET',
        # Require auth tokens to have the following scopes to access this API.
        scopes=[endpoints.EMAIL_SCOPE],
        # OAuth2 audiences allowed in incoming tokens.
        audiences=['your-oauth-client-id.com'])
    def get_user_email(self, request):
        user = endpoints.get_current_user()
        # If there's no user defined, the request was unauthenticated, so we
        # raise 401 Unauthorized.
        if not user:
            raise endpoints.UnauthorizedException
        return EchoResponse(content=user.email())
# [END echo_api]


# [START api_server]
api = endpoints.api_server([api_collection])
# [END api_server]
```

Running the `endpointscfg.py` script results in an AttributeError:

```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 625, in <module>
    main(sys.argv)
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 621, in main
    args.callback(args)
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 479, in _GenOpenApiSpecCallback
    application_path=args.application)
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 324, in _GenOpenApiSpec
    application_path=application_path)
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 181, in GenApiConfig
    module = __import__(module_name, fromlist=base_service_class_name)
  File "/Users/matt/PycharmProjects/gff-api/main.py", line 113, in <module>
    api = endpoints.api_server([api_collection])
  File "/Users/matt/PycharmProjects/gff-api/thirdparty/endpoints/apiserving.py", line 485, in api_server
    apis_app = _ApiServer(api_services, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/matt/PycharmProjects/gff-api/thirdparty/endpoints/apiserving.py", line 241, in __init__
    self.base_paths.add(entry.base_path)
AttributeError: '_ApiDecorator' object has no attribute 'base_path'
```

I played around with the `_ApiServer.__init__` method in `endpoints/apiserving.py` so that it checks the `_ApiDecorator__common_info` if it can't fetch `base_path` directly:

```python
  def __init__(self, api_services, **kwargs):
    self.base_paths = set()

    for entry in api_services[:]:
      # pylint: disable=protected-access
      if isinstance(entry, api_config._ApiDecorator):
        api_services.remove(entry)
        api_services.extend(entry.get_api_classes())
        try:
            self.base_paths.add(entry.base_path)
        except AttributeError:
            self.base_paths.add(entry._ApiDecorator__common_info.base_path)

    # Record the API services for quick discovery doc generation
    self.api_services = api_services
    ...
```

This gets further through the process but results in a new error:

```bash
No handlers could be found for logger "endpoints.apiserving"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 625, in <module>
    main(sys.argv)
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 621, in main
    args.callback(args)
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 479, in _GenOpenApiSpecCallback
    application_path=args.application)
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 324, in _GenOpenApiSpec
    application_path=application_path)
  File "thirdparty/endpoints/endpointscfg.py", line 184, in GenApiConfig
    raise TypeError('%s is not a ProtoRPC service' % service_class_name)
TypeError: main.api_collection is not a ProtoRPC service

```

I decided not to follow the rabbit hole any further -- it doesn't seem like a small job to fix. Any ideas?

items.title: Endpoints 2.0.0b5 raises exception when loading an _ApiDecorator (instead of a protorpc.remote.Service)
items.body:
I ran into a bug when trying to add an API to endpoints' WSGI application instead of each protorpc service. The following sample application works in endpoints 1, but not in endpoints 2.0.0b5:

main.py:
```python
import endpoints
import protorpc


test_api = endpoints.api(
    name='test',
    version='v1',
    title='Test API',
    allowed_client_ids=[endpoints.API_EXPLORER_CLIENT_ID],
    audiences=[],
    scopes=[endpoints.EMAIL_SCOPE]
)

@test_api.api_class(resource_name='tests', path='tests')
class TestService(protorpc.remote.Service):
    pass


ENDPOINTS_APPLICATION = endpoints.api_server([test_api])
```

Error when main.py is loaded:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/wsorvis/google-cloud-sdk/platform/google_appengine/google/appengine/runtime/wsgi.py", line 240, in Handle
    handler = _config_handle.add_wsgi_middleware(self._LoadHandler())
  File "/Users/wsorvis/google-cloud-sdk/platform/google_appengine/google/appengine/runtime/wsgi.py", line 299, in _LoadHandler
    handler, path, err = LoadObject(self._handler)
  File "/Users/wsorvis/google-cloud-sdk/platform/google_appengine/google/appengine/runtime/wsgi.py", line 85, in LoadObject
    obj = __import__(path[0])
  File "/Users/wsorvis/src/endpoints2bug/main.py", line 20, in <module>
    ENDPOINTS_APPLICATION = endpoints.api_server([test_api])
  File "/Users/wsorvis/src/endpoints2bug/lib/endpoints/apiserving.py", line 481, in api_server
    apis_app = _ApiServer(api_services, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/wsorvis/src/endpoints2bug/lib/endpoints/apiserving.py", line 239, in __init__
    self.base_paths.add(entry.base_path)
AttributeError: '_ApiServer' object has no attribute 'base_paths'
```

### Root Cause?

`_ApiServer.__init__` in `endpoints/apiserving.py` has a code path that tries to use `self.base_paths` before it is initialized:

```python
  def __init__(self, api_services, **kwargs):
    """... (docstring cut for brevity)"""
    for entry in api_services[:]:
      # pylint: disable=protected-access
      if isinstance(entry, api_config._ApiDecorator):
        api_services.remove(entry)
        api_services.extend(entry.get_api_classes())
        self.base_paths.add(entry.base_path)

    # Record the base paths
    self.base_paths = set()
    for entry in api_services:
      self.base_paths.add(entry.api_info.base_path)

    ...
```

items.title: Migration guide does not mention pycrypto and ssl library requirements
items.body:
https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/python/endpoints/migrating

Not sure that this is the best place to file this, but I had to add both pycrypto and ssl to the `libraries` section of my app.yaml to get endpoints 2 (2.0.0b5) working. Neither were needed to get endpoints 1 working.

```
libraries:
- name: pycrypto
  version: "latest"
- name: ssl
  version: "latest"
```

items.title: Generated Swagger spec with required fields causes error on GCloud service-management deploy
Compatibility issues with google-api-python-client 1.0+
items.body:
we have been using google-api-python-client 1.0+ for a while now.
I tried to upgrade to endpoint2.0, both libraries have dependency on oauth2client. 

Is this a know issues or is there any work around.
